subSubSection.paragraph:
Note. A complete morphological description of both sexes of this species can be found in
Lucia et al . (2015)
. In this study only female specimens were found, therefore, the diagnostic characters cited belong only to this sex.

Diagnosis. Females can be recognized by the following combination of characters ( Figs. 59–62 ): large body size (body length 18.5–22 mm ); integument dark brown to black except reddish brown on T1–T4; mesosoma with slightly bluish and greenish highlights, head, legs and metasoma without metallic reflections; wings dark brown with blue and violet iridescence; vertex and gena with fine and sparse circular punctures, sparser on upper gena; clypeus at the same level of paraocular area, with the upper margin of the epistomal suture poorly defined; base of labrum with a distinct, large, single capitate tubercle approximately as large as median ocellus; mesoscutellum with scattered, circular punctures throughout the disc and scattered plumose hairs on posterior half; metasoma with short simple hairs (0.1–0.2x OD) barely noticeable on terga disc, longer on last segments and with fine and dense circular punctures (1–2x puncture width), denser on lateral sides. Besides its similarity with
X. dimidiata
, the female of this species also resembles
Xylocopa viridigastra Lepeletier, 1841
(species recorded in Chile , Ecuador and Peru according to Moure, 2012 ). Nevertheless, the female’s mandible of
X . viridigastra
has three teeth on apical margin, labrum with three tubercles of similar size and greenish/violaceous metallic reflections on integument (two mandibular teeth on apical margin, labrum with a single tubercle and metasomal integument without metallic reflections in
Xylocopa simillima
).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material.
Xylocopa simillima : Smith (1854)
based the description of this species on an unknown number of specimens collected in an undetermined locality cited as “ New Holland ” (= Australia ). A specimen deposited in NHMUK that Smith (1874) pointed out as purchased at a sale is here recognized as part of the type series. Although Moure (2012) and
Lucia et al. (2015)
cited that specimen as the holotype , we considered reinterpret it as a syntype , being here designated as the lectotype . Comments. It is not yet clear if the reddish brown areas on the discs of T1–T4 can be useful for differentiate this species. In fact, the lectotype here designated has the discs of T1–T4 with distinct reddish light brown bands, but we found some Colombian specimens with the integument of the metasoma almost black. This situation was also denoted by
Lucia et al . (2015)
in some Argentine exemplars of
X. simillima
and it could be the same variation that happens in other species of the genus such as
X. frontalis (Oliver, 1789)
and
X. nigrocincta Smith, 1854
(
Lucia et al. 2014
).

X. simillima
is a new record for Colombia and was found in the Imerí province of the Boreal Brazilian dominion ( sensu Morrone, 2014 ). Due to its wide distribution and the great similarity with
X. dimidiata
, studying more specimens is needed to determine their variations.
